Jargon Term: * Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour while awake.
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: * Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or drainage. Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: * Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours. If it starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change it as needed to keep site clean and dry.
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: * You will continue to need pain medication once you are home but you can wean it over a few weeks as the discomfort resolves. Make sure that you have regular bowel movements while on narcotic pain medications as they are constipating which can cause more problems. Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay regular.
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Medication

Jargon Term: * No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: * Take Tylenol 650 mg every 6 hours in between your narcotic. If your doctor allows you may also take Ibuprofen to help relieve the pain.
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Medication

Jargon Term: * Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your incisions
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Diet

Jargon Term: * Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat dry
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: Walk 4-5 times a day and gradually increase your activity as you can tolerate
Annotation: Aftercare instructions - patient needs to do - Other

Jargon Term: Call Dr.[**Name (NI) 2347**] office [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2348**] if you experience: -Fevers > 101 or chills -Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other symptoms that concern you.
